title: Derrius Guice undergoes surgery: reports
text:
ASHBURN — Derrius Guice underwent surgery Thursday to repair a torn meniscus in his right knee, sidelining the Redskins running back for the next six to eight weeks.

The operation was performed by Dr. James Andrews, who also repaired Guice’s left knee after the running back tore his ACL as a Redskins rookie in 2018. While Guice’s injury isn’t season-ending, this is the latest setback for Guice, who hurt his knee after just one game to start 2019.

Guice met with Andrews earlier in the day, according to multiple reports, and decided surgery was the best option. The 22-year-old had his meniscus trimmed instead of fully removed, ESPN reported.

The Redskins will now turn to Adrian Peterson in Guice’s absence — a week after the 35-year-old was a healthy scratch against the Philadelphia Eagles. Speaking to reporters Wednesday, coach Jay Gruden said he was confident in Peterson’s ability to produce.

Gruden said he addressed the team before benching for Peterson, but doesn’t see it as an issue moving forward.

“The line loves blocking for Adrian Peterson,” Gruden said. “He’s a big guy. The line likes to block for Derrius Guice, but we only have one ball. That’s in the past.
